conclusion: Two objects, A and B, start from the same location and move in the same direction. Their velocities over time are shown in a graph.
The graph has time on the x-axis and velocity on the y-axis, with curves labeled A and B.
Object A starts with a high velocity and slows down over time. Object B starts from rest, accelerates to a peak velocity, then decelerates.
The points where their velocities are equal are marked as t1, t2, t3, and t4.
The area under a velocity-time graph represents displacement.

premise: The area under a velocity-time graph represents displacement.
conclusion: The difference in displacements of A and B will tell how far apart they are at a given time.

premise: The goal is to find when the difference in displacements is maximized.
conclusion: Find the time when the area under curve A minus the area under curve B is greatest.
Between t=0 and t=t1, object A has a higher velocity than object B.
At t=t1, their velocities are equal.
Between t=t1 and t=t2, object B has a higher velocity than object A.
At t=t2, object A's velocity is zero, and object B is still moving.
Between t=t2 and t=t3, object A starts accelerating again while object B is decelerating.
At t=t3, their velocities are equal again.
Between t=t3 and t=t4, object A has a higher velocity than object B.
At t=t4, their velocities are equal once more.

premise: The separation between A and B at time t is |S_A(t) - S_B(t)|.
conclusion: Find the time t where |S_A(t) - S_B(t)| is maximized.

premise: From t=0 to t=t1, A has a higher velocity than B, so A is ahead.
conclusion: The area under A is greater than under B, so separation increases.

premise: From t=t1 to t=t2, B has a higher velocity than A.
conclusion: B is catching up, reducing the separation.
